Class CCR

java.lang.Object
  CCR

public class CCR
extends java.lang.Object

This class details the condition code register (CCR)
The CCR defines the state of the processor flags at any given time

Author:
Robert Wilson

CCR()
           
 
Method Summary
 void addPropertyChangeListener(java.beans.PropertyChangeListener listener)
           
 java.lang.String getBound_C()
          Bit 0 (C) is the Carry Flag, usually generated by the binary carry from the MSB of the operation (ADC, ADD) -- this is an unsigned overflow C is also used to represent a 'borrow' (a NOT-carry) to and from subtract-like instructions (CMP, NEG, SBC, SUB), and MUL uses C to represent b7 of the result for round-off purposes Data movement and logical operations do not affect C, while arithmetic operations set C, if appropriate
 java.lang.String getBound_E()
          Bit 7 (E) is the entire flag and indicates either the complete machine state (all the registers) or the subset state (PC and CC) is being stacked.
 java.lang.String getBound_F()
          Bit 6 (F) is the FIRQ mask bit If F is set the processor will not recognise interrupts from the FIRQ line NMI, FIRQ, RESET and SWI all set F, while SW12, SW13 and IRQ do not
 java.lang.String getBound_H()
          Bit 5 (H) is the half-carry bit and is used to indicate a carry from b3 in the ALU as a result of an 8-bit addition only (ADC or ADD) H is used by the DAA instruction to perform a (BCD) decimal add adjust operation The state of the H flag is undefined in all subtract-like instructions to allow for future expansion; software must not depend upon a particular state of the H flag after subtract operations
 java.lang.String getBound_I()
          Bit 4 (I) is the IRQ mask bit If I is set the processor will not recognise interrupts from the IRQ line NMI, FIRQ, IRQ, RESET and SWI all set I, while SW12 and SW13 do not
 java.lang.String getBound_N()
          Bit 3 (N) is the negative flag containing the value of the MSB of the result of the preceding operation, thus a negative two's complement result will set N Loads, stores, logical and arithmetic operations all set N if appropriate If two's complement overflow occurs the sign of the result (& the N flag) will be incorrect, thus two's complement branches use the expression (N XOR V) to obtain an always valid sign result
 java.lang.String getBound_V()
          Bit 1 (V) is the Overflow Flag, set when an operation causes a two's-complement arithmetic overflow, which is detected if the carry from the MSB in the binary ALU does not match the carry from the MSB-1 Loads, stores and logical operations clear V, while arithmetic operations set V if appropriate
 java.lang.String getBound_Z()
          Bit 2 (Z) is the Zero Flag, set if the result of the previous operation was identically zero Loads, stores, logical and arithmetic operations set Z if appropriate

getBound_C

public java.lang.String getBound_C()
Bit 0 (C) is the Carry Flag, usually generated by the binary carry from the MSB of the operation (ADC, ADD) -- this is an unsigned overflow C is also used to represent a 'borrow' (a NOT-carry) to and from subtract-like instructions (CMP, NEG, SBC, SUB), and MUL uses C to represent b7 of the result for round-off purposes Data movement and logical operations do not affect C, while arithmetic operations set C, if appropriate

setBound_C

public void setBound_C(java.lang.String bound_C)
Method to implement changes to C register for display

Parameters:
bound_C - - the String representing the C bit

addPropertyChangeListener

public void addPropertyChangeListener(java.beans.PropertyChangeListener listener)

getBound_V

public java.lang.String getBound_V()
Bit 1 (V) is the Overflow Flag, set when an operation causes a two's-complement arithmetic overflow, which is detected if the carry from the MSB in the binary ALU does not match the carry from the MSB-1 Loads, stores and logical operations clear V, while arithmetic operations set V if appropriate

setBound_V

public void setBound_V(java.lang.String bound_V)
Method to implement changes to V register for display

Parameters:
bound_V - - the Z bit

getBound_Z

public java.lang.String getBound_Z()
Bit 2 (Z) is the Zero Flag, set if the result of the previous operation was identically zero Loads, stores, logical and arithmetic operations set Z if appropriate

setBound_Z

public void setBound_Z(java.lang.String bound_Z)
Method to implement changes to z register for display

Parameters:
bound_Z - - the Z bit

getBound_N

public java.lang.String getBound_N()
Bit 3 (N) is the negative flag containing the value of the MSB of the result of the preceding operation, thus a negative two's complement result will set N Loads, stores, logical and arithmetic operations all set N if appropriate If two's complement overflow occurs the sign of the result (& the N flag) will be incorrect, thus two's complement branches use the expression (N XOR V) to obtain an always valid sign result

setBound_N

public void setBound_N(java.lang.String bound_N)

getBound_I

public java.lang.String getBound_I()
Bit 4 (I) is the IRQ mask bit If I is set the processor will not recognise interrupts from the IRQ line NMI, FIRQ, IRQ, RESET and SWI all set I, while SW12 and SW13 do not

setBound_I

public void setBound_I(java.lang.String bound_I)

getBound_H

public java.lang.String getBound_H()
Bit 5 (H) is the half-carry bit and is used to indicate a carry from b3 in the ALU as a result of an 8-bit addition only (ADC or ADD) H is used by the DAA instruction to perform a (BCD) decimal add adjust operation The state of the H flag is undefined in all subtract-like instructions to allow for future expansion; software must not depend upon a particular state of the H flag after subtract operations

setBound_H

public void setBound_H(java.lang.String bound_H)

getBound_F

public java.lang.String getBound_F()
Bit 6 (F) is the FIRQ mask bit If F is set the processor will not recognise interrupts from the FIRQ line NMI, FIRQ, RESET and SWI all set F, while SW12, SW13 and IRQ do not

setBound_F

public void setBound_F(java.lang.String bound_F)

getBound_E

public java.lang.String getBound_E()
Bit 7 (E) is the entire flag and indicates either the complete machine state (all the registers) or the subset state (PC and CC) is being stacked. E is used by the RTI instruction to determine the extent of the un-stacking, thus allowing some interrupt handling routines which work with both fast and slow interrupts FIRQ will clear E while IRQ, NMI, SWI, SWI2 and SWI3 will set E before stacking The E bit associated with the saved registers is in the E flag position in the CC of the stacked state; the E bit in the processor has little meaning

setBound_E

public void setBound_E(java.lang.String bound_E)
